lines.value:
The Cyclops
By Euripides
Written ca. 408 B.C.E
Translated by E. P. Coleridge

O Bromius, unnumbered are the toils I bear because of thee, 
no less now than when I was young and hale; first, when thou wert driven 
mad by Hera and didst leave the mountain nymphs, thy nurses; next, when 
in battle with earth-born spearmen I stood beside thee on the right as 
squire, and slew Enceladus, smiting him full in the middle of his targe 
with my spear. Come, though, let me see; must I confess 'twas all a dream? 
No, by Zeus! since I really showed his spoils to the Bacchic god. And now 
am I enduring to the full a toil still worse than those. For when Hera 
sent forth a race of Tyrrhene pirates against thee, that thou mightest 
be smuggled far away, I, as soon as the news reached me, sailed in quest 
of thee with my children; and, taking the helm myself, I stood on the end 
of the stern and steered our trim craft; and my sons, sitting at the oars, 
made the grey billows froth and foam as they sought thee, my liege, But 
just as we had come nigh Malea in our course, an east wind blew upon the 
ship and drove us hither to the rock of Aetna, where in lonely caverns 
dwell the one-eyed children of ocean's god, the murdering Cyclopes. Captured 
by one of them we are slaves in his house; Polyphemus they call him whom 
we serve; and instead of Bacchic revelry we are herding a godless Cyclops's 
flocks; and so it is my children, striplings as they are, tend the young 
thereof on the edge of the downs; while my appointed task is to stay here 
and fill the troughs and sweep out the cave, or wait upon the ungodly Cyclops 
at his impious feasts. His orders now compel obedience; I have to scrape 
out his house with the rake you see, so as to receive the Cyclops, my absent 
master, and his sheep in clean caverns.
But already I see my children driving their browsing flocks towards 
me.
What means this? is the beat of feet in the Sicinnis dance the 
same to you now as when ye attended the Bacchic god in his revelries and 
made your way with dainty steps to the music of lyres to the halls of Althaea?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
The CHORUS OF SATYRS enters, driving a flock of goats and sheep. Servants 
follow them.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Hush, children! and bid our servants fold the flocks in the 
rock-roofed cavern.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
I see the hull of a ship from Hellas at the shore, and men, 
that wield the oar, on their way to this cave with some chieftain. About 
their necks they carry empty vessels and pitchers for water; they are in 
want of food. Luckless strangers! who can they be? They know not what manner 
of man our master Polyphemus is, to have set foot here in his cheerless 
abode and come to the jaws of the cannibal Cyclops in an evil hour. But 
hold ye your peace, that we may inquire whence they come to the peak of 
Sicilian Aetna.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
ODYSSEUS and his companions enter. They carry baskets for provisions 
and water jars.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Pray tell us, sirs, of some river-spring whence we might draw 
a draught to slake our thirst, or of someone willing to sell victuals to 
mariners in need.
Why, what is this? We seem to have chanced upon a city of the Bromian 
god; here by the caves I see a group of Satyrs. To the eldest first I bid 
"All hail!
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: All hail, sir! tell me who thou art, and name thy country.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Odysseus of Ithaca, king of the Cephallenians' land.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: I know him for a prating knave, one of Sisyphus' shrewd offspring.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: I am the man; abuse me not.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Whence hast thou sailed hither to Sicily?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: From Ilium and the toils of Troy.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
How was that? didst thou not know the passage to thy native 
land?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Tempestuous winds drove me hither against my will.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: God wot! thou art in the same plight as I am.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Why, wert thou too drifted hither against thy will?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: I was, as I pursued the pirates who carried Bromius off.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: What land is this and who are its inhabitants?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: This is mount Aetna, the highest point in Sicily.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: But where are the city-walls and ramparts?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: There are none; the headlands, sir, are void of men.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Who then possess the land? the race of wild creatures?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: The Cyclopes, who have caves, not roofed houses.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Obedient unto whom? or is the power in the people's hands?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: They are rovers; no man obeys another in anything.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Do they sow Demeter's grain, or on what do they live?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: On milk and cheese and flesh of sheep.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Have they the drink of Bromius, the juice of the vine?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: No indeed! and thus it is a joyless land they dwell in.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Are they hospitable and reverent towards strangers?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Strangers, they say, supply the daintiest meat.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: What, do they delight in killing men and eating them?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: No one has ever arrived here without being butchered.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Where is the Cyclops himself? inside his dwelling?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: He is gone hunting wild beasts with hounds on Aetna.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Dost know then what to do, that we may be gone from the land?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Not I, Odysseus; but I would do anything for thee.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Sell us food, of which we are in need.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: There is nothing but flesh, as I said.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Well, even that is a pleasant preventive of hunger.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
And there is cheese curdled with fig-juice, and the milk of 
kine.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Bring them out; a man should see his purchases.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: But tell me, how much gold wilt thou give me in exchange?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: No gold bring I, but Dionysus' drink.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Yes, it was Maron, the god's son, who gave me a draught.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: What! Maron whom once I dandled in these arms?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: The son of the Bacchic god, that thou mayst learn more certainly.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Is it inside the ship, or hast thou it with thee?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: This, as thou seest, is the skin that holds it, old sir.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Why, that would not give me so much as a mouthful.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: This, and twice as much again as will run from the skin.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Fair the rill thou speakest of, delicious to me.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Shall I let thee taste the wine unmixed, to start with?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: A reasonable offer; for of a truth a taste invites the purchase.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Well, I haul about a cup as well as the skin.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Come, let it gurgle in, that I may revive my memory by a pull 
at it.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: No, i' faith, but I smell it.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Taste it then, that thy approval may not stop at words.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Did it not gurgle finely down thy throttle?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Aye that it did, to the ends of my fingers.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Well, we will give thee money besides.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Only undo the skin, and never mind the money.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Bring out the cheeses then and lambs.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
I will do so, with small thought of any master. For let me 
have a single cup of that and I would turn madman, giving in exchange for 
it the flocks of every Cyclops and then throwing myself into the sea from 
the Leucadian rock, once I have been well drunk and smoothed out my wrinkled 
brow. For if a man rejoice not in his drinking, he is mad; for in drinking 
it's possible for this to stand up straight, and then to fondle breasts, 
and to caress well tended locks, and there is dancing withal, and oblivion 
of woe. Shall not I then purchase so rare a drink, bidding the senseless 
Cyclops and his central eye go hang?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Hearken, Odysseus, let us hold some converse with thee.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Well, do so; ours is a meeting of friends.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Did you take Troy and capture the famous Helen?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Aye, and we destroyed the whole family of Priam.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
After capturing your blooming prize, were all of you in turn 
her lovers? for she likes variety in husbands; the traitress! the sight 
of a man with embroidered breeches on his legs and a golden chain about 
his neck so fluttered her, that she left Menelaus, her excellent little 
husband. Would there had never been a race of women born into the world 
at all, unles it were for me alone!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Alack! yonder comes the Cyclops; what shall we do?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Then truly are we lost, old sir! whither must we fly?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Inside this rock, for there ye may conceal yourselves.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Dangerous advice of thine, to run into the net!
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: No danger; there are ways of escape in plenty in the rock.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
No, never that; for surely Troy will groan and loudly too, 
if we flee from a single man, when I have oft withstood with my shield 
a countless host of Phrygians. Nay, if die we must, we will die a noble 
death; or, if we live, we will maintain our old renown at least with credit.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
The CYCLOPS enters as SILENUS goes into the cave. The CYCLOPS, not noticing 
ODYSSEUS and his companions, addresses the CHORUS in 
anger.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
A light here! hold it up! what is this? what means this idleness, 
your Bacchic revelry? Here have we no Dionysus, nor clash of brass, nor 
roll of drums. Pray, how is it with my newly-born lambs in the caves? are 
they at the teat, running close to the side of their dams? Is the full 
amount of milk for cheeses milked out in baskets of rushes? How now? what 
say you? One of ye will soon be shedding tears from the weight of my club; 
look up, not down.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
There! my head is bent back till I see Zeus himself; I behold 
both the stars and Orion.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: 'Tis laid; be thy throat only ready.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Are, the bowls too full of milk?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Aye, so that thou canst swill off a whole hogshead, so it please 
thee.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Sheep's milk or cows' milk or a mixture of both?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Whichever thou wilt; don't swallow me, that's all.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Not I; for you would start kicking in the pit of my stomach 
and kill me by your antics.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Catching sight Of ODYSSEUS and his followers
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
SILENUS comes out of the cave. He has made himself appear as though 
he had just suffered a terrible beating.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Oh! oh! poor wretch that I am, pounded to a fever.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: By whom? who has been pounding thy head, old sirrah?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
These are the culprits, Cyclops, all because I refused to let 
them plunder thee.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Did they not know I was a god and sprung from gods?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
That was what I told them, but they persisted in plundering 
thy goods, and, in spite of my efforts, they actually began to eat the 
cheese and carry off the lambs; and they said they would tie thee in a 
three-cubit pillory and tear out thy bowels by force at thy navel, and 
flay thy back thoroughly with the scourge; and then, after binding thee, 
fling thy carcase down among the benches of their ship to sell to someone 
for heaving up stones, or else throw thee into a mill.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Oh, indeed! Be off then and sharpen my cleavers at once; heap 
high the faggots and light them; for they shall be slain forthwith and 
fill this maw of mine, what time I pick my feast hot from the coals, waiting 
not for carvers, and fish up the rest from the cauldron boiled and sodden; 
for I have had my fill of mountain-fare and sated myself with banquets 
of lions and stags, but 'tis long I have been without human flesh.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Truly, master, a change like this is all the sweeter after 
everyday fare; for just of late there have been no fresh arrivals of strangers 
at these caves.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Hear the strangers too in turn, Cyclops. We had come near the 
cave from our ship, wishing to procure provisions by purchase, when this 
fellow sold us the lambs and handed them over for a stoup of wine to drink 
himself, a voluntary act on both sides, there was no violence employed 
at all. No, there is not a particle of truth in the story he tells; now 
that he has been caught selling thy property behind thy back.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Keep that for thyself; with my own eyes I saw thee sell the 
goods to the strangers; and if I lie, perdition catch my sire! but injure 
not the strangers.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Ye lie; for my part I put more faith in him than Rhadamanthus, 
declaring him more just. But I have some questions to ask. Whence sailed 
ye, strangers? of what country are you? what city was it nursed your childhood?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
We are Ithacans by birth, and have been driven from our course 
by the winds of the sea on our way from Ilium, after sacking its citadel.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Are ye the men who visited on Ilium, that bordereth on Scamander's 
wave, the rape of Helen, worst of women?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: We are; that was the fearful labour we endured.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
A sorry expedition yours, to have sailed to the land of Phrygia 
for the sake of one woman
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
It was a god's doing; blame not any son of man. But thee do 
we implore, most noble son of Ocean's god, speaking as free-born men; be 
not so cruel as to slay thy friends on their coming to thy cave, nor regard 
us as food for thy jaws, an impious meal; for we preserved thy sire, O 
king, in possession of his temple-seats deep in the nooks of Hellas; and 
the sacred port of Taenarus and Malea's furthest coves remain unharmed; 
and Sunium's rock, the silver-veined, sacred to Zeus-born Athena, still 
is safe, and Geraestus, the harbour of refuge; and we did not permit Phrygians 
to put such an intolerable reproach on Hellas. Now in these things thou 
too hast a share, for thou dwellest in a corner of the land of Hellas beneath 
Aetna's fire-streaming rock; and although thou turn from arguments, still 
it is a custom amongst mortal men to receive shipwrecked sailors as their 
suppliants and show them hospitality and help them with raiment; not that 
these should fill thy jaws and belly, their limbs transfixed with spits 
for piercing ox-flesh. The land of Priam hath emptied Hellas quite enough, 
drinking the blood of many whom the spear laid low, with the ruin it has 
brought on widowed wives, on aged childless dames, and hoary-headed sires; 
and if thou roast and consume the remnant,-a meal thou wilt rue,-why, where 
shall one turn? Nay, be persuaded by me, Cyclops; forego thy ravenous greed 
and choose piety rather than wickedness; for on many a man ere now unrighteous 
gains have brought down retribution.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
I will give thee a word of advice! as for his flesh, leave 
not a morsel of it, and if thou eat his tongue, Cyclops, thou wilt become 
a monstrous clever talker.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Wealth, manikin, is the god for the wise; all else is mere 
vaunting and fine words. Plague take the headlands by the sea, on which 
my father seats himself! Why hast thou put forward these arguments? I shudder 
not at Zeus's thunder, nor know I wherein Zeus is a mightier god than I, 
stranger; what is more, I reck not of him; my reasons hear. When he pours 
down the rain from above, here in this rock in quarters snug, feasting 
on roast calf's flesh or some wild game and moistening well my up-turned 
paunch with deep draughts from a tub of milk, I rival the thunder-claps 
of Zeus with my artillery; and when the north wind blows from Thrace and 
sheddeth snow, I wrap my carcase in the hides of beasts and light a fire, 
and what care I for snow? The earth perforce, whether she like it or not, 
produces grass and fattens my flocks, which I sacrifice to no one save 
myself and this belly, the greatest of deities; but to the gods, not I! 
For surely to eat and drink one's fill from day to day and give oneself 
no grief at all, this is the king of gods for your wise man, but lawgivers 
go hang, chequering, as they do, the life of man! And so I will not cease 
from indulging myself by devouring thee; and thou shalt receive this stranger's 
gift, that I may be free of blame,-fire and my father's element yonder, 
and a cauldron to hold thy flesh and boil it nicely in collops. So in with 
you, that ye may feast me well, standing round the altar to honour the 
cavern's god.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
The CYCLOPS goes into his cave, driving ODYSSEUS' men before 
him.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Alas! escaped from the troubles of Troy and the sea, my barque 
now strands upon the whim and forbidding heart of this savage. O Pallas, 
mistress mine, goddess-daughter of Zeus, help me, help me now; for I am 
come to toils and depths of peril worse than all at Ilium; and thou, O 
Zeus, the stranger's god, who hast thy dwelling 'mid the radiant stars, 
behold these things; for, if thou regard them not, in vain art thou esteemed 
the great god Zeus, though but a thing of naught.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
He follows the CYCLOPS reluctantly. SILENUS also goes 
in.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: reappearing with a look of horror
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
What news, Odysseus? has the Cyclops, most godless monster, 
been feasting on thy dear comrades?
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
Aye, he singled out a pair, on whom the flesh was fattest and 
in best condition, and took them up in his hand to weigh.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: How went it with you then, poor wretch?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
When we had entered yonder rocky abode, he lighted first a 
fire, throwing logs of towering oak upon his spacious hearth, enough for 
three wagons to carry as their load; next, close by the blazing flame, 
he placed his couch of pine-boughs laid upon the floor, and filled a bowl 
of some ten firkins, pouring white milk thereinto, after he had milked 
his kine; and by his side he put a can of ivy-wood, whose breadth was three 
cubits and its depth four maybe; next he set his brazen pot a-boiling on 
the fire, spits too he set beside him, fashioned of the branches of thorn, 
their points hardened in the fire and the rest of them trimmed with the 
hatchet, and the blood-bowls of Aetna for the axe's edge. Now when that 
hell-cook, god-detested, had everything quite ready, he caught up a pair 
of my companions and proceeded deliberately to cut the throat of one of 
them over the yawning brazen pot; but the other he clutched by the tendon 
of his heel, and, striking him against a sharp point of rocky stone, dashed 
out his brains; then, after hacking the fleshy parts with glutton cleaver, 
he set to grilling them, but the limbs he threw into his cauldron to seethe. 
And I, poor wretch, drew near with streaming eyes and waited on the Cyclops; 
but the others kept cowering like frightened birds in crannies of the rock, 
and the blood forsook their skin. Anon, when he had gorged himself upon 
my comrades' flesh and had fallen on his back, breathing heavily, there 
came a sudden inspiration to me. I filled a cup of this Maronian wine and 
offered him a draught, saying, "Cyclops, son of Ocean's god, see here what 
heavenly drink the grapes of Hellas yield, glad gift of Dionysus." He, 
glutted with his shameless meal, took and drained it at one draught, and, 
lifting up his hand, he thanked me thus "Dearest to me of all my guests! 
fair the drink thou givest me to crown so fair a feast." Now when I saw 
his delight, I gave him another cup, knowing the wine would make him rue 
it, and he would soon be paying the penalty. Then he set to singing; but 
I kept filling bumper after bumper and heating him with drink. So there 
he is singing discordantly amid the weeping of my fellow-sailors, and the 
cave re-echoes; but I have made my way out quietly and would fain save 
thee and myself, if thou wilt. Tell me then, is it your wish, or is it 
not, to fly from this unsocial wretch and take up your abode with Naiad 
nymphs in the halls of the Bacchic god? Thy father within approves this 
scheme; but there! he is powerless, getting all he can out of his liquor; 
his wings are snared by the cup as if he had flown against bird-lime, and 
he is fuddled; but thou art young and lusty; so save thyself with my help 
and regain thy old friend Dionysus, so little like the Cyclops.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Best of friends, would we might see that day, escaping the 
godless Cyclops!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Hear then how I will requite this vile monster and rescue you 
from thraldom.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Tell me how; no note of Asiatic lyre would sound more sweetly 
in our ears than news of the Cyclops' death.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Delighted with this liquor of the Bacchic god, he fain would 
go a-reveling with his brethren.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
I understand; thy purpose is to seize and slay him in the thickets 
when clone, or push him down a precipice.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Not at all; my plan is fraught with subtlety.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: What then? Truly we have long heard of thy cleverness.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
I mean to keep him from this revel, saying he must not give 
this drink to his brethren but keep it for himself alone and lead a happy 
life. Then when he falls asleep, o'ermastered by the Bacchic god, I will 
put a point with this sword of mine to an olive-branch I saw lying in the 
cave, and will set it on fire; and when I see it well alight, I will lift 
the heated brand, and, thrusting it full in the Cyclops' eye, melt out 
his sight with its blaze; and, as when a man in fitting the timbers of 
a ship makes his auger spin to and fro with a double strap, so will I make 
the brand revolve in the eye, that gives the Cyclops light and will scorch 
up the pupil thereof.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Ho! ho! how glad I feel! wild with joy at the contrivance!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
That done, I will embark thee and those thou lovest with old 
Silenus in the deep hold of my black ship, my ship with double banks of 
oars, and carry you away from this land.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Well, can I too lay hold of the blinding brand, as though the 
god's libation had been poured? for I would fain have a share in this offering 
of blood.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Indeed thou must, for the brand is large, and thou must help 
hold it.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
How lightly would I lift the load of e'en a hundred wains, 
if that will help us to grub out the eye of the doomed Cyclops, like a 
wasp's nest.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Hush! for now thou knowest my plot in full, and when I bid 
you, obey the author of it; for I am not the man to desert my friends inside 
the cave and save myself alone. And yet I might escape; I am clear of the 
cavern's depths already; but no! to desert the friends with whom I journeyed 
hither and only save myself is not a righteous course.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: The CYCLOPS enters. He is obviously drunk.
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
returning with the wine-skin. He is followed by SILENUS, who is also 
drunk.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: And who is Bacchus? some reputed god?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: The greatest god men know to cheer their life.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: I like his after-taste at any rate.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: This is the kind of god he is; he harmeth no man.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: But how does a god like being housed in a wine-skin?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Put him where one may, he is content there.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: It is not right that gods should be clad in leather.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
What of that, provided he please thee? does the leather hurt 
thee?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: I hate the wine-skin, but the liquor we have here I love.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Stay, then, Cyclops; drink and be merry.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Must I not give my brethren a share in this liquor?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: No, keep it thyself and thou wilt appear of more honour.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Give it my friends and I shall appear of more use.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Revelling is apt to end in blows, abuse, and strife.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: I may be drunk, but no man will lay hands on me for all that.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Better stay at home, my friend, after a carouse.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Who loves not revelling then is but a simpleton.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: But whoso stays at home, when drunk, is wise.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: What shall we do, Silenus? art minded to stay?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
That I am; for what need have we of others to share our drink, 
Cyclops?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Well, truly the turf is soft as down with its fresh flowering 
plants.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: That no one passing by may upset it.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Nay, but thy purpose is to drink upon the sly; set it between 
us.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: SILENUS is drinking steadily and stealthily.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Noman. What boon shall I receive of thee to earn my thanks?
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: I will feast on thee last, after all thy comrades.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Fair indeed the honour thou bestowest on thy guest, sir Cyclops!
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: No, but it kissed me for my good looks.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Thou shalt smart, if thou kiss the wine when it kisses not 
thee.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Oh! but it did, for it says it is in love with my handsome 
face.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: H'm! how is it mixed? just let me make sure.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Perdition! give it me at once.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Oh, no! I really cannot, till I see thee with a crown on, and 
have another taste myself.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
No really, but the wine is so luscious. Thou must wipe thy 
lips, though, to get a draught.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: There! my lips and beard are clean now.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Bend thine elbow gracefully, and then quaff thy cup, as thou 
seest me do, and as now thou seest me not.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Burying his face in his cup
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: I drunk it off at a draught with much pleasure.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Stranger, take the skin thyself and be my cup-bearer.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Well, at any rate the grape is no stranger to my hand.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: In it goes! keep silence, that is all.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: A difficult task when a man is deep in his cups.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Here, take and drink it off; leave none. Thou must be silent 
and only give in when the liquor does.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: God wot! it is a clever stock that bears the grape.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Aye, and if thou but swallow plenty of it after a plentiful 
meal, moistening thy belly till its thirst is gone, it will throw thee 
into slumber; but if thou leave aught behind, the Bacchic god will parch 
thee for it.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Ha! ha! what a trouble it was getting out! This is pleasure 
unalloyed; earth and sky seem whirling round together; I see the throne 
of Zeus and all the godhead's majesty. Kiss thee! no! There are the Graces 
trying to tempt me. I shall rest well enough with my Ganymede here; yea, 
by the Graces, right fairly; for I like lads better than the wenches.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: What! Cyclops, am I Ganymede, Zeus's minion?
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: attempting to carry him into the cave
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: I am undone, my children; outrageous treatment waits me.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: Dost find fault with thy lover? dost scorn him in his cups?
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value: Woe is me! most bitter shall I find the wine ere long.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value: SILENUS is dragged into the cave by the CYCLOPS.
lines.speaker: SILENUS

lines.value:
Up now, children of Dionysus, sons of a noble sire, soon will 
yon creature in the cave, relaxed in slumber as ye see him, spew from his 
shameless maw the meat. Already the brand inside his lair is vomiting cloud 
of smoke; and the only reason we prepared it was to burn the Cyclops' eye; 
so mind thou quit thee like a man.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
I will have a spirit as of rock or adamant; but go inside, 
before my father suffers any shameful treatment; for here thou hast things 
ready.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
O Hephaestus, lord of Aetna, rid thyself for once and all of 
a troublesome neighbour by burning his bright eye out. Come, Sleep, as 
well, offspring of sable Night, come with all thy power on the monster 
god-detested; and never after Troy's most glorious toils destroy Odysseus 
and his crew by the hands of one who recketh naught of God or man; else 
roust we reckon Chance a goddess, and Heaven's will inferior to hers.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: Silent we stand with bated breath.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
In then, and mind your fingers grip the brand, for it is splendidly 
red-hot.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Thyself ordain who first must seize the blazing bar and burn 
the Cyclops' eye out, that we may share alike whate'er betides.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Standing where I am before the door, I am too far off to thrust 
the fire into his eye.
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
Why, then, thou art in the same plight as I; for somehow or 
other I sprained my ankle, standing still.
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
Yes, and my eyes are full of dust or ashes from somewhere or 
other.
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value: These are sorry fellows, worthless as allies.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Because I feel for my back and spine, and express no wish to 
have my teeth knocked out, I am a coward, am I? Well, but I know a spell 
of Orpheus, a most excellent one, to make the brand enter his skull of 
its own accord, and set alight the one-eyed son of Earth.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Long since I knew thou wert by nature such an one, and now 
I know it better; I must employ my own friends; but, though thou bring 
no active aid, cheer us on at any rate, that I may find my friends emboldened 
by thy encouragement.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: ODYSSEUS goes back into the cave.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
That will I do; the Carian shall run the risk for us; and as 
far as encouragement goes, let the Cyclops smoulder.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Sweet indeed the triumph-song; pray sing it to us, Cyclops.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value: Why dost thou cry out, Cyclops?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Thou art indeed a sorry sight.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Aye, and a sad one, too.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Didst fall among the coals in a drunken fit?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Then there is no one hurting thee after all.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: How, pray, could no man have made thee blind?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Thou mockest me; but where is this Noman?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
It was the stranger, vile wretch! who proved my ruin, that 
thou mayst understand rightly, by swilling me with the liquor he gave me.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Ah! wine is a terrible foe, hard to wrestle with.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Tell me, I adjure thee, have they escaped or are they still 
within?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
During the following lines, ODYSSEUS and his men slip by the CYCLOPS, 
despite his efforts to stop them.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Here they are ranged in silence, taking the rock to screen 
them.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Close against the rock. Hast caught them?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Trouble on trouble! I have run my skull against the rock and 
cracked it
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: Aye, and they are escaping thee.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: This way, was it not? 'Twas this way thou saidst.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: They are getting round thee on the left.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Alas! I am being mocked; ye jeer me in my evil plight.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value: They are no longer there; but facing thee that stranger stands.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Master of villainy, where, oh! where art thou?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Some way from thee I am keeping careful guard over the person 
of Odysseus.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value: What, a new name! hast changed thine?
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Yes, Odysseus, the name my father gave me. But thou wert doomed 
to pay for thy unholy feast; for I should have seen Troy burned to but 
sorry purpose, unless I had avenged on thee the slaughter of my comrades.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Woe is me! 'tis an old oracle coming true; yes, it said I should 
have my eye put out by thee on thy way home from Troy; but it likewise 
foretold that thou wouldst surely pay for this, tossing on the sea for 
many day.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
Go hang! E'en as I say, so have I done. And now will I get 
me to the beach and start my hollow ship across the sea of Sicily to the 
land of my fathers.
lines.speaker: ODYSSEUS

lines.value:
Thou shalt not; I will break a boulder off this rock and crush 
thee, crew and all, beneath my throw. Blind though I be, I will climb the 
hill, mounting through yonder tunnel.
lines.speaker: CYCLOPS

lines.value:
As for us, henceforth will we be the servants of Bacchus, sharing 
the voyage of this hero Odysseus.
lines.speaker: LEADER
